Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: A casual conversation drifts toward personal topics but nothing particularly sensitive is mentioned.
Story:
I sat at the kitchen table, my phone buzzing with messages from my family group chat. My mom’s voice echoed in my head, “We really want you there for the holiday trip this weekend. It won’t be the same without you.” As a sister, I knew how much these gatherings meant to everyone, especially after the year we’d had. But as I scrolled through my messages, I saw a text from the volunteer coordinator reminding me about the support group meeting I was scheduled to help with that same weekend. 

During a recent session, one of the group members had shared a little about their struggles, nothing too sensitive, but enough that I felt protective of their privacy. Now, as my brother joked about my “mysterious volunteer work” at the dinner table, my family’s curiosity grew. “Come on, tell us a story! Just a little bit,” my sister pleaded. I felt torn—my family wanted me to be present and share, but my role as a volunteer demanded I keep even the smallest details private. The pressure built inside me, my loyalty to my family clashing with my responsibility to those I helped.
